item.title: Forza Horizon 6's release date might have been revealed early, and it's allegedly coming sooner than anticipated
item.content:encoded:
A new Developer Direct stream from Xbox is happening next week, and with it we'll get a "deep dive" into Forza Horizon 6. This is the previously announced next entry in the open-world driving series, which will take us to Japan. However, a surprise may have been spoiled early.

Via user XBOX INFINITE on X/Twitter (hat tip to Xbox Era), we've received what could be the first look at an in-game promotion of Forza Horizon 6 and its pre-order bonuses. When asked about the screenshot, the user claims they got the pop-up after exiting their garage in Forza Horizon 5.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

The pop-up is placed on top of new art showcasing one of the stunning environments we can expect to visit during the next Horizon Festival. Pre-orders allegedly include an extra vehicle: "Pre-order now and get a pre-tuned and exclusive Ferrari J50 in Forza Horizon 6!"

There's also the promise of "over 550 real-world cars" at launch and the largest open-world in the series yet, with the Premium Edition adding Early Access (on 15th May, thus making the regular release date 19th May), VIP Membership, Welcome Pack, Car Pass, Time Attack Car Pack, and a post-launch Italian Passion Car Pack plus two Premium Expansions. It's all believable if you've been paying attention to past entries and their DLC offerings.

Xbox and Playground Games haven't confirmed or denied anything yet, but it wouldn't be the first time an in-game pop-up in previous games has revealed what's next in a series, so I'm personally leaning towards someone having pressed a button way too early. Oops.

Forza Horizon 6 is currently set to release exclusively on Xbox Series X/S and PC (Xbox and Steam), but a PS5 port at some point is likely, since its predecessor has already sold over 5m copies on Sony's console.

item.title: Umamusume developer apologises after AI studio backlash, says it will not use generative AI "without prior notice"
item.content:encoded:
Maybe it's Neigh-belline.

Japanese video game developer Cygames has released a new statement regarding its use of AI, after last week announcing its intention to create an AI-focused subsidiary company, which stirred up a certain amount of discourse.

Writing on social media platform X, the studio - which is known for a variety of popular games including Umamusume: Pretty Derby - apologised for the "concern" it had caused. It added its original announcement was a "simplified" one, which did not address "any of the current problems and social debates" around generative AI.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Cygames stated that art produced via generative AI is not used in its products, and all of its current games have been "crafted from the technical know-how and manual work" of its staff. It furthered that the studio "won't implement generative AI into [its] products without prior notice" to the community.

On the topic of its community, the studio said it holds those of us who love games - including creators and artists - "in the highest regard". Cygames intends to continue honouring free expression while striving to deliver "the best in entertainment", it closed, with another apology to its fans and supporters.

You, of course, don't need me to tell you how rampant the AI discourse in the industry is at the moment. Just this morning, we reported on Hazelight founder Josef Fares' thoughts about the technology, where the developer said he doesn't see AI "taking over", and nor does he see any issue with using AI as long as it isn't generative. Meanwhile, a number of other Japanese studios such as Square Enix and Sega have expressed interest in AI use.

As for Cygames, Umamusume: Pretty Derby won the best mobile game award at last year's The Game Awards.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/umamusume-developer-apologises-after-ai-studio-backlash-says-it-will-not-use-generative-ai-without-prior-notice
